title: RK Maribor Branik
text:
Rokometni klub Maribor Branik (), commonly referred to as RK Maribor Branik or simply Branik, is a <a href="handball">handball</a> club from <a href="Maribor">Maribor</a>, Slovenia. As of the 2021–22 season, it competes in the <a href="Slovenian%20First%20League%20of%20Handball">Slovenian First League</a>. Branik play their home games at <a href="Tabor%20Hall">Tabor Hall</a>, a 3,261 capacity multi-purpose sports venue in Maribor. Between 2004 and 2010, the team was known as RK Klima Petek Maribor due to sponsorship reasons. Their biggest success is reaching the final of the <a href="Slovenian%20Handball%20Cup">Slovenian Handball Cup</a> twice and reaching the quarter-finals of the <a href="EHF%20Cup">EHF Cup</a> in the <a href="2012%E2%80%9313%20EHF%20Cup">2012–13</a> season.
History.
Handball in Maribor.
The first <a href="handball">handball</a> team in <a href="Maribor">Maribor</a> was formed in 1925, when the women's selection of the "1. SSK MB" played their first <a href="Czech%20handball">Czech handball</a> match at the <a href="Ljudski%20vrt">Ljudski vrt</a> area. In 1928, the 1. SSK Maribor have won the national league. The first men's handball team, named "Polet", was formed in 1949. They were renamed to "Branik" in 1951, when they participated in the Yugoslav First League qualifiers. In 1954, Branik have won their first Slovenian Republic League title, and were promoted to the Yugoslav First League. The women's team have won the league one year later, in 1955. Between 1955 and 1968, Branik did not achieve any major success and were even relegated to the local <a href="Styria%20%28Slovenia%29">Styrian</a> League in 1966, but returned to the top Slovenian division two years later. They were relegated again in 1972, but once again returned in 1979 after spending a few years in the local regional leagues. In 1977, the team was merged with Kovinar Tezno to form "Maribor". The team was struggling in the next decade and did not achieve any major results. After the independence of Slovenia, the team was reformed with a help from some former handball players, including Marko Šibila. They reached the 3. DRL (Third National Handball League).
Maribor Branik.
In 2003, a new club called Maribor Branik was founded. In their first season, the team was promoted to the 2. DRL East. In 2005–06, they were promoted to the 1. B DRL, where they stayed until the 2008–09 season, when the team was promoted to the top tier <a href="Slovenian%20First%20League%20of%20Handball">Slovenian First League of Handball</a>. In the same year, they also finished third in the <a href="Slovenian%20Handball%20Cup">Slovenian Handball Cup</a>. In their first season in the top division, they finished eighth and were runners-up of the Slovenian Handball Cup, where they lost to <a href="RK%20Celje">Celje</a> in the final. As runners-up, they gained a place in the <a href="2010%E2%80%9311%20EHF%20Cup%20Winners%27%20Cup">2010–11 EHF Cup Winners' Cup</a>. They reached the quarter-finals, where they lost to the Spanish side <a href="SDC%20San%20Antonio">San Antonio</a>. In the same season, Branik finished fifth in the league. They again finished fifth in the 2011–12 season, and were eliminated in the quarter-finals of the 2011–12 <a href="EHF%20Challenge%20Cup">EHF Challenge Cup</a> by <a href="Maccabi%20Tel%20Aviv">Maccabi Tel Aviv</a> from Israel. The most successful international season for the club was in 2012–13, when they reached the group stages of the <a href="2012%E2%80%9313%20EHF%20Cup">EHF Cup</a>, defeating Dudelange, <a href="Handknattleiksf%C3%A9lag%20K%C3%B3pavogs">Kópavogs</a> and Siscia in the qualifications. They were drawn in the group with Danish team <a href="Team%20Tvis%20Holstebro">Tvis Holstebro</a>, Norwegian <a href="Elverum%20H%C3%A5ndball">Elverum</a> and Polish <a href="Wis%C5%82a%20P%C5%82ock%20%28handball%29">Wisła Płock</a>. With seven points out of six games, Maribor Branik qualified to the quarter-finals of the competition, where they were eliminated by <a href="Frisch%20Auf%20G%C3%B6ppingen">Göppingen</a> with 57–56 on aggregate. In 2013–14 and 2014–15, the club finished third in the Slovenian League, which is their best result since the establishment. The club was about to enter the regional <a href="SEHA%20League">SEHA League</a> alongside Celje and <a href="RK%20Gorenje">Gorenje</a> in the 2014–15 season, but all three Slovenian clubs refused entry due to unacceptable financial requirements. In the 2016–17 season, Maribor Branik reached the final of the Slovenian Cup for the second time in their history, where they lost to Celje 36–28.
Arena.
Maribor Branik play their home matches at a 3,261 capacity <a href="Tabor%20Hall">Tabor Hall</a> in the <a href="Tabor%20District">Tabor District</a> of <a href="Maribor">Maribor</a>. The reserve venue of the club is Lukna Sports Hall, a 2,100 capacity all-seater indoor hall, also located in Maribor.
Supporters and rivalries.
Kristijan Petek, the former president of the club, was the first to organize a fan group which would support the team at home matches. As he was also the owner of the air conditioning company Klima Petek, which was the main sponsor of the club, the fan group was composed of employees of the company. In 2010, when Andrej Bauman has been appointed a new director of Maribor Branik, the club gained a new group of fans, named Maribor Supporters, which supposedly consisted of the younger members of <a href="Viole%20Maribor">Viole Maribor</a>, the supporters of <a href="association%20football">football</a> club <a href="NK%20Maribor">NK Maribor</a>.
In February 2012, members of the Maribor Supporters chanted a song about the <a href="Srebrenica%20massacre">Srebrenica massacre</a> against the Bosnian team <a href="RK%20Grada%C4%8Dac">Gradačac</a> during the 2011–12 <a href="EHF%20Challenge%20Cup">EHF Challenge Cup</a> match. The match was temporarily suspended, and the incident received wide coverage in the Slovenian and Bosnian media. The group was banned by Maribor Branik from attending any home matches, and a police investigation was ordered.
Maribor Branik do not have any major rivals; however, matches between Maribor Branik and <a href="RK%20Celje">RK Celje</a> are dubbed as the Styrian derby (), named after <a href="Styria%20%28Slovenia%29">Styria</a>, with <a href="Maribor">Maribor</a> and <a href="Celje">Celje</a> being the two largest cities in the region. Matches between Maribor Branik and <a href="RK%20Jeruzalem%20Ormo%C5%BE">RK Jeruzalem Ormož</a> are also called Styrian derby or Neighbourhood derby ().
Colours, kits and crest.
Initially, the club's colours were white and black, which are the main colours of the Branik Sports Association. However, at the start of the 2011–12 season, RK Maribor Branik changed their main colour to purple due to popularity of <a href="NK%20Maribor">NK Maribor</a>, the most successful <a href="association%20football">association football</a> club in the country, which main colour is purple. A decade later, before the start of the 2021–22 season, Maribor Branik switched back to their original colours as the home kit was changed to white, and the away kit to black. The club's first crest was a shield-shape with a black and white abstract portrayal of a handball player. In 2012, they changed the colours of the crest to purple and white.
